newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian dollar opens weaker on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Canadian dollar opens weaker on profit-taking.

text.p: * Canada's dollar opened weaker in light trading on Friday at C$1.3752 (US$0.7271) as overseas investors continued to take profits in last night's trading session, dealers said.
* They said Japanese investors unloaded Canadian assets as the yen gained considerable strength against the Canadian and Australian dollars.

"The market will watch the Aussie dollar and the Canada (dollar) together, so you're seeing the mid-level currencies taking a hit here," said Reid Farrill, corporate foreign exchange adviser for CIBC Wood Gundy.
Some analysts also speculated that renewed talk of the Quebec separation issue in Canada's general election campaign might be causing some market nervousness toward the Canadian dollar.
The western-based Reform Party and the Quebec separatist Bloc Quebecois party in the past week have upped their efforts to make national unity the bellwether issue of the election.

"It may well be this focus on the separation issue that is prompting some offshore players to cut their Canada holdings a bit, especially in light of the imminent long weekend in both the U.S. and London," one trader said.
"If you don't live here, you're saying 'what the hell is going on in Canada,'" the trader added.
Markets are closed on Monday for Memorial Day in the United States and a bank holiday in Great Britain.
Analysts said they expected markets to wind down early today, which could produce some "erratic moves" by the Canada dollar in morning trade.
Farrill said the Canada dollar had probably reached the end of its "unwinding" following the U.S. Federal Reserve decision on Tuesday to hold interest rates steady.
"I think we're pretty well finished (the downward trend), and corporate Canada will be a very active seller of Canadian dollars as this thing approaches C$1.3800 (US$0.7246)," Farrill said.
On the crosses, the Canadian dollar fell to 84.20 yen from Thursday's close of 84.52 and dipped to 1.2316 marks from Thursday's 1.2342 marks.
